title: Path attribute on module fails to compile on non-windows platforms when going up a directory
body:
I tried this code:

```rust
mod my_module {
   #[path = "../dir/my_file.rs"]
   mod my_file;
}
```

I expected to see this happen: To be consistent across platforms. Maybe compile on Linux and Mac as it does on Windows when `./dir/my_file.rs` exists.

Instead, this happened: Only on Linux and Mac...

```
couldn't read tests/my_module/../dir/my_file.rs: No such file or directory (os error 2)
```

### Meta

```
# also occurs for
rustc 1.55.0-nightly (7c3872e6b 2021-06-24)
```

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.53.0 (53cb7b09b 2021-06-17)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 53cb7b09b00cbea8754ffb78e7e3cb521cb8af4b
commit-date: 2021-06-17
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.53.0
LLVM version: 12.0.1
```

**Workaround 1**

```rust
#[path = "dir"]
mod my_module {
   #[path = "my_file.rs"]
   mod my_file;
}
```

**Workaround 2**

```rust
#[path = ""]
mod my_module {
   #[path = "dir/my_file.rs"]
   mod my_file;
}
```

By the way, I didn't end up using this or wanting this in the end, but just letting you know.
